President George W: Bush and British Prime Minister Tony Blair publicly discussed their partnership on the Iraq war, indicating that the United States did not stand alone in the conflict.
Rep: Debbie Wasserman Schultz claimed that the United States "stood alone in the war in Iraq," but this statement was fact-checked and found to be false. The United States had the support of 35 countries, as stated by President Bush in his address to the nation.
The White House released a list of 49 na: further confirming that the claim of standing alone was inaccurate.
The British Parliament: considered one of the United States' closest allies, did not support potential U.S. military strikes in Syria, highlighting the lack of unanimity among nations in supporting U.S. actions.
